customer_name: Elizabeth Yutzy Marianna Yutzy Jonas Yutzy
site_name: Elizabeth Yutzy Marianna Yutzy Jonas Yutzy

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
****A female Pomeranian puppy (#22-25, DOB 5/24/2025) was weak and lethargic and had a clear discharge from her
nostrils. She was heard to be coughing and wheezing. She would not open her right eye although no discharge was
observed at the time of inspection. The licensee stated that the eye had some discharge on it on the previous day and it
was cleaned and a silver based solution placed on it (no instructions from attending veterinarian on this treatment). The
licensee also stated that the puppy was coughing and not well on the previous day. A veterinarian was not consulted for
evaluation and proper treatment. The puppy had been given an injection of penicillin that was formulated for livestock.
She was being given a mixture of water, karo syrup and electrolytes, which was lapped up slowly. Respiratory conditions
in very young dogs can worsen quickly and cause death if not properly and promptly evaluated and treated. Eye
conditions can be painful and worsen if not properly diagnosed and treated quickly.
Licensees must ensure that they establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care, including the use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. When animals are identified with
injuries or illness, they must seek care by their veterinarian to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases. A medical
record of the illness and treatment must be created and made available to APHIS officials.
Correct by ensuring that the animal listed above is examined and treated by a licensed veterinarian by close of business
on July 1, 2025.
NOTE: The veterinarian was called at the end of the inspection and a morning appointment was made. Instructions for
further care was given.
****An injectible antibiotic, Norocillin formulated for livestock, had been used for the injection given to the puppy. Using
this formulation, it was difficult for the licensee to know the proper dose for the dog and did not consult the attending
veterinarian. The licensee stated that she guessed and gave the puppy "a drop" but there is no certainty in knowing if it
was the proper dose. Medications which are being used in a manner different than what is written on the label or without
the instructions of a licensed veterinarian may be harmful to the animals or may not work as anticipated. The licensee
must ensure that all medications have written instructions for their use in the dogs obtained from a veterinarian and that
these instructions are followed to ensure the health and safety of the animals. This medicine has also been improperly
stored as it was not refrigerated at the recommended range of 36-46 degrees Fahrenheit. The bottle was in the kennel
area where the temperature was approximately 75 degrees Fahrenheit. Improperly stored medications may lose their
efficacy and quality. Improperly dosed animals may not improve. The licensee must ensure that all medications are
properly stored according to their labeled directions and that all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times.
Corrected during inspection by removal of medication.

A female Pomeranian puppy (#22-25, DOB 5/24/2025) has been receiving treatment for an eye condition and respiratory
condition for 1 day prior to the day of inspection. There is no record of treatment except what the licensee reported
verbally to the inspector. Dealers must keep medical records for dogs documenting all required information including the
date and identification of animals treated, and if a problem is identified (such as a disease, injury, or illness), the date and
a description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures
performed, when appropriate; fully detailed treatment plans, and results of examinations conducted by licensed
veterinarians. The licensee must ensure medical records are created and maintained and fully document all procedures,
treatments, and examinations for each adult dog and puppy.
Correct by July 1, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
****A female Pomeranian puppy (#22-25, DOB 5/24/2025) was weak and lethargic and had a clear discharge from her

3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
A female Pomeranian puppy (#22-25, DOB 5/24/2025) has been receiving treatment for an eye condition and respiratory 
condition for 1 day prior to the day of inspection. There is no record of treatment except what the licensee reported 
verbally to the inspector. Dealers must keep medical records for dogs documenting all required information including the 
date and identification of animals treated, and if a problem is identified (such as a disease, injury, or illness), the date and 
a description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures 
performed, when appropriate; fully detailed treatment plans, and results of examinations conducted by licensed 
veterinarians. The licensee must ensure medical records are created and maintained and fully document all procedures, 
treatments, and examinations for each adult dog and puppy. 
Correct by July 1, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
